required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Muscle Typology and Strength Training Adaptations
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Muscle Typology and Training Frequency on Chronic Strength Training Adaptations

brief_summary.textblock:
The overall aim of this project is to investigate if the responsiveness to chronic resistance training is dependent on the muscle typology. In a second aim we will investigate the most optimal training frequency for slow-twitchers and fast-twitchers. For the latter we hypothesize that slow-twitchers might cope better with higher frequencies and higher volumes compared to fast-twitchers.
Male and female adult participants (18-45y) will be recruited. The subjects' muscle typology will be non-invasively estimated in the leg muscles by measurement of muscle carnosine using H-MRS. In total 21 subjects (11 slow and 10 fast subjects) will participate. Subjects will be assigned to a whole-body resistance training exercise protocol of 9 weeks in wich arm A and leg A will train 3 times per week and arm B and leg B will train 2 times per week. Before and following the training period, subjects will be subjected to different measurements (fitness level, muscle volume, strength tests, blood sampling, muscle biopsies).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All participants will receive the same training intervention but the subjects are divided into two groups based on an inherent physiological characteristic: the muscle typology. A slow typology group (people with a lot of slow muscle fibers) and a fast typology group (people with a lot of fast muscle fibers). Each participant will train their legs and arms unilateral and one arm and one leg will train two times per week, while the other arm and leg will train three times per week for 9 weeks. The assignment of the limbs to the 3x/week condition and the 2x/week condition is randomized. The training outcomes of the two groups will be compared as well as the within subject differences between training two times per week or training 3 times per week.
study_design_info.masking_description: The participants don't know their muscle typology during the study. All participants do the same training intervention, no drugs are taken.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline muscle volume at 9 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post the 9 weeks training period
primary_outcome.description: Muscle volume of the legs and the upper arms - MRI

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline dynamic muscle strength at 3 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre, mid and post 9 weeks training period
primary_outcome.description: Upper legs and upper arms - strength training devices

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline dynamic muscle strength at 6 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre, mid and post 9 weeks training period
primary_outcome.description: Upper legs and upper arms - strength training devices

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline dynamic muscle strength at 9 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre, mid and post 9 weeks training period
primary_outcome.description: Upper legs and upper arms - strength training devices

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline isometric muscle strength at 9 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period
primary_outcome.description: Upper legs and upper arms - Biodex

primary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle fiber type specific hypertrophy at 9 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of baseline antropometry at 9 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of baseline skeletal muscle protein content at 9 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period
secondary_outcome.description: Histochemistry and protein content of markers of relevance for skeletal muscle function

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of baseline histochemistry at 9 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period
secondary_outcome.description: Histochemistry of markers of relevance for skeletal muscle function

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from basline fatigue feeling over 9 weeks training period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed every training during the 9 weeks training period
secondary_outcome.description: Number of repetitions during every training, questionnaire (VAS-scale) before every training, RPE after every training

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline fasting insulin, glucose, cholesterol and triglycerides at 9 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post 9 weeks training period

arm_group.description: The participants receive the same exercise training intervention, but they are divided in two groups: a slow typology group and a fast typology group based on their inherent physiological characteristics: their muscle fiber type.

The participants receive the same exercise training intervention, but they are divided in two groups: a slow typology group and a fast typology group based on their inherent physiological characteristics: their muscle fiber type.

intervention.description: Exercise training: Participants perform 9 weeks of strength training at 60% of their 1RM.
Training frequency: leg A and arm A of the participants train 3 times per week, leg B and arm B train 2 times per week.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fast or slow muscle typology
- 18 - 45 years old
- no strength training experience
Exclusion Criteria:
- Vegan/vegeterian diet
- Supplement intake
- chronic diseases
- Hypertension,
- Smoking
- Medication use
- Coagulation disorder, infectious diseases

facility.name: Department of Movement and Sports Sciences, Ghent University
